timeline.summary: A correspondence between an Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York and an unnamed recipient regarding a subpoena and a request for email correspondence. The subpoena seeks recordings of Jeffrey Epstein’s phone calls (excluding attorney calls) and requests all email correspondence of Jeffrey Epstein from July 6, 2019, through July 11, 2019, excluding emails between Estin and Marc Fernich, Weinberg, and Reid Weingarten. The sender emphasizes the need for expedited receipt of the requested materials and provides contact information.

On July 7, 2019, Martin Weinberg informed [REDACTED] that the indictment in the U.S. v. Jeffrey Epstein case was expected to be unsealed and assigned to a district judge around 9:15 a.m. the following morning. Weinberg offered to contact [REDACTED] after Epstein met with him.  [REDACTED] confirmed receipt of the indictment and noted awareness of potential privilege issues related to the search conducted at Epstein’s residence, stating a warrant and inventory would be delivered. Weinberg sent a follow-up email on July 6th, attaching the indictment and providing contact information for the Assistant U.S. Attorneys involved.

Reid Weingarten and Marty Weinberg will appear tomorrow on behalf of Jeffrey Epstein, and the Buffalo team will provide a download of information. An Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York is involved, referencing case file EFTA00018146.

On July 8, 2019, EFTA00026635 received a communication regarding the presentation of Jeffrey Epstein in the case of United States v. Epstein (19 Cr. 490). The sender anticipates the indictment will be unsealed tomorrow morning and is offering assistance to the recipient with any relevant information. Jeffrey Epstein is represented by Martin Weinberg and Reid Weingarten.

On July 8, 2019, an email chain discusses the unsealing of the indictment in United States v. Epstein (19 Cr. 490) concerning Jeffrey Epstein. A redaction request (EFTA00030226.pdf) was sent to Judge Pitman to unseal the documents and a meeting was scheduled for 9:15 AM. Counsel for Epstein, Martin Weinberg and Reid Weingarten, were involved. The expectation was that the indictment would be unsealed first thing the following morning and a copy would be provided.

This email chain discusses the legal representation of Jeffrey Epstein, specifically referencing Martin Weinberg Law and Steptoe & Johnson LLP. An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York provided links to the websites of these law firms. The email is dated July 8, 2019.

Pitman in the Southern District of New York on July 8, 2019. The charges against Epstein are two counts: sex trafficking conspiracy (18 U.S.C. § 371) and the substantive offense of sex trafficking (18 U.S.C. § 1591). The government, represented by Geoffrey S. Berman and Reid Weingarten, is seeking detention due to Epstein’s alleged risk of flight and danger presented by his conduct, including alleged exploitation of underage girls and potential witness tampering. Epstein is represented by attorneys Martin Weinberg and Reid Weingarten.  The judge informed Epstein of his rights, and the parties discussed the charges, the government’s desire for detention, and the scheduling of a detention hearing for Thursday, July 11th. Key points include the government’s arguments focusing on Epstein’s wealth, mobility, and past conduct (specifically, the Florida investigation and nonprosecution agreement), and the defense’s assertion that the charges relate to an older period of conduct and questioning the scope of the nonprosecution agreement. The case is being considered in light of a potential statute of limitations issue and concerns about the victims involved.

This document records Jeffrey Epstein’s initial appearance in the Southern District of New York on July 8, 2019, following his arrest on July 6, 2019. United States Attorney Geoffrey Berman and defense attorneys Reid Weingarten, Martin Weinberg, and Marc Fernich appeared on behalf of the prosecution and defendant, respectively. Epstein is charged with two counts: sex trafficking conspiracy and the substantive offense of sex trafficking, allegedly involving the sexual abuse of underage girls at his residences in New York and Florida. The court explained Epstein’s rights as a defendant, and the government sought detention pending trial, citing significant risk of flight and danger due to Epstein’s wealth, international travel, and previous offenses. The defense argued that the charges were based on old conduct and that the non-prosecution agreement in Florida was not applicable, requesting a continuance to present their case. The court scheduled a detention hearing for July 11, 2019, at 2:00 PM, and ordered Epstein to be detained.

Reid Weingarten sent contact information for the U.S. Attorney’s team involved in the case *U.S. v. Epstein* to be used as a point of contact for Mr. Epstein. The information included multiple office and cell phone numbers belonging to Assistant U.S. Attorneys from the Southern District of New York.

The email chain discusses the attorneys representing Jeffrey Epstein. The original email asks for information about Epstein’s attorneys, and the response lists Martin Weinberg, Reid Weingarten, and Marc Fernich as the attorneys who have appeared for him. The email also provides contact information for the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York.

On July 11, 2019, Adam Johnson, a Supervisory Staff Attorney, sent a revised subpoena to Stephanie Scannell and Eric Blachman, requesting email correspondence from inmate Jeffrey Epstein (76318-054) between July 6, 2019, and July 11, 2019. The subpoena excluded communications between Epstein and Marc Fernich, Weinberg I, and Reid Weingarten. The original subpoena was deemed incorrect due to missing attorney contact information. The return date for the subpoena was set for July 12, 2019.

A subpoena was issued on July 11, 2019, requesting recordings of Jeffrey Epstein’s phone calls, excluding those involving attorneys. Simultaneously, a written request was made for Jeffrey Epstein’s email correspondence from July 6, 2019, through July 11, 2019, excluding emails exchanged with Marc Fernich, Martin Weinberg, and Reid Weingarten. The subpoena’s return date was set for July 12, 2019.

An email exchange discusses the broad scope of the sex trafficking statute. Reid Weingarten, representing a client, informed his team that he had spoken with his client and planned to have an “interesting conversation” early next week. Weingarten’s son indicated the statute is broad, allowing a person to potentially determine their own situation. The email originated from [REDACTED] to [REDACTED] and references a meeting at Odeon involving Jeffrey Epstein.

v. Epstein case (19 Cr. 490). *   Reid Weingarten, a defense attorney, is coordinating with government counsel ([REDACTED]) and Judge Berman’s chambers. *   Discussions revolve around the government's bail memorandum and the defendant’s motion for bail. *   Attendees express availability for meetings on Monday morning, with a proposed agenda. *   The government provided an attached document (Government’s reply in support of its detention memo and in opposition to the defendant’s motion for bail) filed this afternoon.

An email chain discusses the potential involvement of Curcio due to his son's employment. Geoffrey Berman reported a conversation with Reid Weingarten, who indicated his client might contact the team and that his son believed the sex trafficking statute was broad.

v. Epstein (19 Cr. 490 (RMB)). *   There are multiple email exchanges discussing scheduling a meeting to discuss the case, particularly regarding a visit to Reid Weingarten following the hearing. *   The government expresses a willingness to speak with Weingarten on Monday morning, contingent on a general understanding of the client’s priorities. *   The government provided the bail memorandum and supporting exhibits to Judge Berman. *   There's a request to ensure all parties are kept informed via communication to account for varying team availability.

Martin G. Weinberg, Esq., requested a copy of records obtained from Institution 1 for the U.S. v. Epstein case, requesting they be provided as discovery rather than a public filing.  A U.S. Attorney attached the Government's reply and exhibits in support of the detention memo and opposition to the defendant's motion for bail to Judge Berman.  Communication occurred between Weinberg, Reid Weingarten, and the Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding the discovery process.

The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York is requesting Judge Richard M. Berman to exclude speedy trial time between July 15, 2019, and July 18, 2019, in the case of *United States v. Jeffrey Epstein*. This request is made with the consent of the defense counsel (Martin Weinberg and Reid Weingarten) and is based on 18 U.S.C. § 3161(h)(7)(A) and (B) in the interests of justice.

On July 15, 2019, Reid Weingarten communicated with multiple parties regarding bail topics. He expressed a desire to discuss potential solutions with others, citing difficulties with demanding judges and a potential conflict. He indicated he would work on a draft protective order and general discovery.  A U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York requested information about a passport and inquired about Mr. Epstein’s prior citizenship or legal residency status.

An Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York is requesting information regarding Benjamin Epstein’s passport and any prior citizenship or legal permanent residency status outside of the United States. This request was initiated by Martin G. Weinberg and Reid Weingarten, and follows a previous email exchange concerning bail topics.

On July 24, 2019, a Notice of Appearance for Additional Counsel was filed in the case of United States of America v. Epstein (Case Number 19-2221) before the Court of Appeals, 2nd Circuit. The notice was filed on behalf of the Appellee, the United States of America, by Reid Weingarten and Donnell G. Bolden. The document, titled "Moe NOA.pdf," was electronically stamped and stored within the notice cart.

On July 25, 2019, individuals within the Epstein defense team (Martin G. Weinberg, Reid Weingarten, Michael Miller) were coordinating efforts to produce materials related to the US v. Epstein case. Andy was involved in the goal of producing the materials before a conference. Martin Weinberg intended to sign a Protective Order and requested information regarding the discovery's format and expected delivery.

Martin G. Weinberg sent an email to Michael Miller regarding a formal preservation/production request for materials related to the “US v Epstein” case. The email included a follow-up request for questions and identified the document as EFTA00014535.

Martin Weinberg, Esq., contacted Reid Weingarten and Marty to discuss preservation requests related to the US v. Epstein case. He requested clarification on whether he needed to proactively request preservation from the US Attorney’s Office (AUSA) in SD Fla or if the request would be forwarded by Weingarten’s team. Weinberg anticipated a delay in responding due to travel and suggested sending a follow-up letter focusing on notifying other DOJ districts. Weingarten responded, acknowledging the delay and offering to incorporate the letter into their response.

An email chain concerning the case “U.S. v. Epstein” is being distributed between Michael C. Miller of Steptoe & Johnson LLP and various recipients, including Reid Weingarten, Martin G. Weinberg, Michael Scavelli, Morgan Lucas, Jim Brochin, and Jason Meade. The email contains an attached letter and includes standard legal disclaimers regarding confidential and privileged information.

On August 2, 2019, Martin G. Weinberg, an Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, sent an email regarding the case *US v Epstein*. The email was sent to Michael Miller, Reid Weingarten, and Martin G. Weinberg, requesting that all future communications about the case include all four individuals. The email also included a standard disclaimer regarding the transmission of privileged legal information.

On August 5, 2019, a “Defective Document” notice was filed in the case of *United States of America v. Epstein* (Case Number 19-2221) before the 2nd Circuit Court of Appeals. The notice was on behalf of Jeffrey Epstein and included additional counsel (Martin G. Weinberg and Reid Weingarten). The document was electronically mailed to the Assistant U.S. Attorney and the listed counsel.  The document's original filename was “DonnellBolden_192221_2624335_Defective_Document_Notice_142.pdf.”

On August 5, 2019, a “Defective Document” notice was filed in the case of *United States of America v. Epstein* (Case Number 19-2221) before the Court of Appeals, 2nd Circuit. The notice was filed on behalf of Jeffrey Epstein by Martin G. Weinberg and Reid Weingarten. The document was electronically mailed to those recipients and associated with document number [2624335].

On August 5, 2019, a “CURED DEFECTIVE NOTICE OF ADDITIONAL COUNSEL” was filed in the case of *United States of America v. Epstein* (Case Number 19-2221) by Jeffrey Epstein’s legal team, represented by Reid Weingarten and associates at Steptoe & Johnson. The notice was filed with the 2nd Circuit Court of Appeals. The document is identified as EFTA00028078 and was subsequently stored in the court’s notice cart for Quality Control 1. Access to the document is permitted for attorneys of record and parties involved in the case, with PACER fees applying to other users.

On August 5, 2019, a “Form B” was filed on behalf of Jeffrey Epstein in the case of *United States of America v. Epstein* (Case Number 19-2221) before the Court of Appeals, 2nd Circuit. The document was filed by Reid Weingarten and associates, and associated with CM/ECF.[2624204]. Electronic notification was sent to several individuals, including Donnell G. Bolden, Deputy Clerk. The document was stamped with a date and file number on August 5, 2019.

On August 6, 2019, the Court of Appeals, 2nd Circuit, recorded a docket activity transaction for the case of United States of America v. Epstein (Case Number: 19-2221). Martin G. Weinberg and Reid Weingarten were added as attorneys of record. The document was labeled EFTA00020942 and stored in the notice cart for Quality Control 1. A note indicates judicial conference policy allows attorneys and parties to receive free electronic copies, with PACER fees applying to others.

An email chain discusses ongoing investigations related to the case of *US v. Epstein*. A press release from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) was sent to Michael Miller, Marty, and Reid Weingarten, indicating investigations initiated by the Attorney General, including a potential FBI investigation into the cause of death. Further information regarding the apparent cause of death and Mr. Epstein’s observation status is pending.

Michael Miller received an email from [REDACTED] regarding the ongoing investigation into Jeffrey Epstein’s death, initiated by the Attorney General and including an FBI investigation. The email included a press release from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) summarizing available information, noting ongoing investigations and a lack of updates regarding the cause of death and Mr. Epstein’s observations. Reid Weingarten and Martin G. Weinberg were also copied on the communications.

On August 10, 2019, an individual (identified as "[REDACTED]") communicated with Michael Miller regarding the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein’s death. The individual confirmed a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) official contacted Epstein’s brother to discuss arrangements for the transport and logistics of Epstein’s body upon readiness. The individual advised Miller to contact BOP directly if needed and directed inquiries to the FBI tip line (1-800-CALL-FBI) while noting ongoing investigations. A press release regarding the situation was attached.  A follow-up email from the same sender confirmed an FBI investigation into Epstein’s death was underway and ongoing efforts to obtain additional information would be communicated.

An email was sent forwarding correspondence regarding the US v. Epstein case. The email directs Michael Miller to copy Martin Weinberg and Reid Weingarten as legal counsel for notifications, providing their email addresses.

Michael Miller forwarded a press release regarding the US v. Epstein case, sourced from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP). The press release contains all available information from BOP. He confirms an FBI investigation into the death has been initiated and anticipates it will be rigorous.

Michael Miller inquired about confirmation of Jeffrey Epstein’s death via email to Martin G. Weinberg and Reid Weingarten on August 10, 2019. Weinberg responded on July 26, 2019, acknowledging receipt and sending a formal preservation/production request for materials related to the US v. Epstein case.

Martin G. Weinberg, along with Miller, Michael, Reid Weingarten, and the attorney for Mr. Epstein’s Estate, contacted [REDACTED] requesting access to videos of Mr. Epstein’s jail cell at the MCC, specifically between midnight and 7 AM on August 10, 2019. [REDACTED] responded stating they were unable to share the information at that time and requested any potentially useful information for their investigation.

Martin G. Weinberg emailed Marty, Michael Miller, Reid Weingarten, and Alex regarding a potential civil forfeiture discussion related to the US v. Epstein case. He offered availability at 9:30 AM the following morning and requested a dial-in be circulated.

On August 14, 2019, Martin G. Weinberg contacted individuals involved in the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein’s death, requesting contact information for Epstein’s defense counsel, Reid Weingarten, and Stacey Richman (representing Mark Epstein). Weinberg specifically requested assurance that seized computers and documents would not be accessed by the “case team” without establishing a taint team and protection protocols due to attorney-client and work product privilege. He also inquired about the timing of potential motions to dismiss the indictment and any delays in the investigation. Weinberg offered to provide a list of attorneys to a taint prosecutor upon identification.

Martin G. Weinberg, Esq., and Michael Reid Weingarten are authorized to discuss potential civil forfeiture issues related to the US v. Epstein case. Weinberg is offering to speak with the recipient at 9:30 AM the following day, August 15, 2019, to hear their perspective.

On August 16, 2019, Martin G. Weinberg and Reid Weingarten, previously legal counsel for Jeffrey Epstein, requested information regarding videos of Epstein’s jail cell at the MCC, specifically from midnight to 7 AM on August 10, 2019. They sent this request to [REDACTED] (USANYS) after [REDACTED] (USANYS) had received a similar inquiry. [REDACTED] (USANYS) responded stating they were unable to share the information at that time and requested further details if available.

On August 20, 2019, Michael C. Miller of Steptoe & Johnson LLP sent an attachment to [REDACTED] regarding a filing related to Jeffrey Epstein. The email was received by Reid Weingarten, Morgan Lucas, and Michael Scavelli. The email included a standard confidentiality disclaimer from Steptoe & Johnson LLP.

Michael C. Miller, a partner at Steptoe & Johnson LLP, received and signed a stipulation to withdraw the appeal in the case of United States of America v. Epstein (2nd Circuit Docket No. 19-2221). He forwarded the signed stipulation to the sender for filing. The email chain involves communication between Miller and Reid Weingarten, Morgan Lucas, and redacted recipients.

On August 21, 2019, the FRAP 42 stipulation, with prejudice, was filed in the case of *United States of America v. Epstein* (Case Number 19-2221) before the Court of Appeals, 2nd Circuit. The stipulation was sent electronically to Assistant U.S. Attorneys Martin G. Weinberg and Reid Weingarten. The document was stamped with a date and file number. EFTA00031718 is associated with this filing.

On August 21, 2019, a FRAP 42 Stipulation with prejudice was filed in the case of United States of America v. Epstein (Case Number 19-2221) before the Court of Appeals, 2nd Circuit. The document was electronically mailed to Assistant U.S. Attorneys Martin G. Weinberg and Reid Weingarten, along with Margaret Lain. The document itself is an order stipulation named “Order_stipulation.”

Attorney Marty Weinberg and Michael Miller (of Steptoe & Johnson LLP). *   Weinberg requested a call to ensure alignment on concerns regarding MCC conditions and the client’s death. *   Miller proposed delivering a drive containing materials to the courtroom for production, suggesting an envelope drop-off as an alternative if a meeting outside the courthouse couldn’t be arranged. *   Miller expressed confidence in the Epstein defense team adhering to the protective order and anticipated minimal issues during the court proceedings. *   The communication involved scheduling and logistics related to the presentation of evidence.

*   A status conference is scheduled for August 27, 2019, at 10:30 AM in Courtroom 110 of the Thurgood Marshall United States Courthouse (40 Foley Square) for the case USA v. Epstein (Case 1:19-cr-00490-RMB). *   Judge Richard M. Berman is presiding over the conference. *   Notifications have been sent electronically to numerous parties, including legal representatives for the defendant, the US Department of Justice, and victims (James L. Brochin, Marc Allan Fernich, Michael Campion Miller, Reid Weingarten, Martin Gary Weinberg, and others). *   A digital stamp confirms the electronic filing of the document.

A series of emails and court documents relate to a status conference in the case of *USA v. Epstein* (Case 1:19-cr-00490-RMB). The conference is scheduled for August 27, 2019, at 10:30 AM in Courtroom 110 of the Thurgood Marshall Courthouse in New York. Key individuals involved include Judge Richard M. Berman and attorneys representing the prosecution and the defendant (James L. Brochin, Marc Allan Fernich, Michael Campion Miller, Reid Weingarten, Martin Gary Weinberg, and Michael Gerard Scavelli). A notice was electronically mailed to these recipients, along with the U.S. Department of Justice’s e-mail addresses. The documents include a court order and the main document itself.

The hearing was presided over by Judge Richard M. Berman, with representatives from the U.S. Attorney’s Office and defense counsel present. **Key Events and Participants:** *   **Initial Housekeeping:** Judge Berman addressed the participants, outlining the purpose of the hearing—to consider the motion to dismiss due to Epstein’s death. He also acknowledged the significant effort involved and expressed gratitude for the work of the prosecutors and victims. *   **Government’s Argument:** The government, led by Geoffrey Berman, argued that the death of Epstein necessitated the dismissal of the case due to the lack of a live defendant. They emphasized the need for a full and transparent investigation and highlighted the potential for further investigation into co-conspirators. They referenced the legal precedent set by the *U.S. v. Wright* case concerning abatement. *   **Defense’s Argument:** Defense counsel, led by Reid Weingarten, strongly opposed the dismissal, arguing that the court had an inherent authority to continue investigating and pursuing justice, regardless of Epstein's death. They raised concerns about the government’s handling of the investigation and questioned the credibility of the medical examiner’s findings regarding the cause of death. They invoked precedent from *U.S. v. Heaton* and suggested the possibility of a parallel investigation by the court. *   **Victim Testimonies:** Multiple Jane Doe victims, represented by Gloria Allred’s firm, offered statements detailing their experiences and the ongoing trauma caused by Epstein’s actions. They expressed a desire for justice and accountability. *   **Legal Discussions:** Throughout the hearing, the lawyers discussed relevant legal principles, including the “abatement” doctrine, the Crime Victims' Rights Act, and the role of the government in investigating and prosecuting crimes. The discussion centered on the court’s authority to continue the case despite Epstein's death. **Outcome (as presented):** The hearing concluded with Judge Berman stating that he would consider the arguments and would likely move forward with an inquiry into the circumstances surrounding Epstein's death, reinforcing the importance of victims’ rights and ongoing investigation. **Additional Notes:** *   The text contains several references to ongoing investigations and potential further legal action. *   There were discussions regarding the handling of evidence, the role of the FBI, and the need for transparency in the investigation. *   The hearing showcased the complex legal and ethical issues involved in a case where the defendant has died before a trial concludes.

This document is a letter from U.S. District Judge Richard M. Berman to Professor Bruce A. Green regarding Green’s expert opinion and opinion piece concerning the U.S. v. Epstein case. Green was retained as an expert on legal ethics and provided an affidavit recommending the disqualification of David Boies from representing Ghislaine Maxwell. Judge Berman expresses surprise that this recommendation wasn't disclosed alongside Green’s opinion piece and questions Green’s interpretation of Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 57 and the Crime Victims' Rights Act, arguing the piece may have attempted to silence Maxwell and Boies. The letter is copied to Martin G. Weinberg, Reid Weingarten, and David Boies.

An email was sent from [REDACTED] to [REDACTED] regarding a meeting with Reid Weingarten concerning Jeffrey Epstein. The email was dated November 19, 2019, and marked as “Normal” importance. An unnamed attachment was included.

On November 19, 2019, at 9:30 PM, a tentative telephone conversation (TC) occurred between Reid Weingarten and “I” (likely a representative of USANYS) in RD’s office. The meeting lasted 30 minutes and was classified as X-PERSONAL. The event was created on November 19, 2019, at 9:15 PM and has a priority level of 5.

On November 19, 2019, an email was sent from “USANYS” to [REDACTED] regarding a tentative meeting with Reid Weingarten concerning Jeffrey Epstein. The email was marked as “Normal” importance and included an unnamed attachment.

On November 19, 2019, from 21:30 to 22:00, there was a personal meeting at the Es office involving Reid Weingarten and (USANYS) <I> regarding Jeffrey Epstein. The event was created on November 19, 2019, at 23:51:15 +0000 and has a priority of 5.

On November 19, 2019, at 21:30:00 +0000, a meeting (Event: TC with Reid Weingarten re Epstein) took place in Reid Weingarten’s office (RD’s office) organized by (USANYS). The meeting was classified as X-PERSONAL. Attendees included (USANYS) [REDACTED]. The purpose was a call between Reid Weingarten and another individual regarding an indictment, with the intention of limiting discussion. The meeting was flagged with a 15-minute reminder and noted for inclusion of the Epstein team.

Reid Weingarten is requesting a call with [REDACTED] and [REDACTED] to discuss the indictment related to Jeffrey Epstein. The sender intends to limit the conversation due to the sensitive nature of the information. The email is being circulated to the Epstein team for their awareness.

The U.S. Department of Justice’s Office of the Inspector General (OIG) interviewed Reid Weingarten, Senior Counsel to the Inspector General for the U.S. Department of Justice Office of General Counsel, regarding deceased Federal Bureau of Prisons inmate Jeffrey Epstein. Weingarten stated that Epstein’s estate is asserting attorney-client privilege and refuses to be interviewed by the OIG.

The appeal numbered 19-2221-cr regarding Jeffrey Epstein is dismissed with prejudice by agreement of the parties. Costs, expenses, and fees are not recoverable. The stipulation was executed on August 2019 by Reid Weingarten and Martin G. Weinberg representing Jeffrey Epstein and the United States of America, respectively.
